metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: automatic weather station of desert station, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the desert station from January 1 to December 31, 2022. The site (100.9872°E, 42.1135°N) was located on a desert surface in the desert, which is near Ejin Banner, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 1054 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45AC; 5 and 10 m, north), wind speed profile (010C; 5 and 10 m, north), wind direction (020C, 10m), air pressure (CS100; 2 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0 m), soil moisture profile (ML3; -0.02, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.6, -1.0 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m and Ta_10 m; RH_5 m and RH_10 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_5 m and Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_2 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_60 cm, Ts_100 cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_2 cm, Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_60 cm, Ms_100 cm) (%).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2022-6-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for monitoring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used in oasis–desert ecosystems involves the use of an eddy covariance system and scintillometer to acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data. This is supplemented by hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations, which include radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, observed with a 10-minute average period.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting data in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced in such regions is the ecological environment degradation, including the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, as observed in river basins like the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Feature Specification.Answer: air temperature, relative humidity at multiple heights, air pressure, precipitation, wind speed and direction, radiation components, surface radiation temperature, soil heat flux, soil moisture, soil temperature at various depths

Definition.Question: What is an automatic weather station and how is it used in the context of data collection for meteorological studies?
Definition.Answer: An automatic weather station is a facility used to observe and record meteorological data, often including parameters like air temperature, humidity, wind speed, wind direction, precipitation, and radiation. In meteorological studies, such as those conducted at the Heihe River Basin, these stations are equipped with sensors positioned at various heights and orientations to ensure precise data collection, which can then be processed for quality control and analysis.

Definition.Question: What does the term 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of measuring energy and carbon exchange in ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: In the context of measuring energy and carbon exchange in ecosystems, an 'eddy covariance system' refers to a technique used to measure and calculate the vertical turbulent fluxes within the atmosphere. It is commonly used to assess exchanges of water vapor, carbon dioxide, and energy between the land surface and the atmosphere, providing critical data for understanding ecosystem dynamics, especially in oasis-desert systems.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the 黑河流域地表过程综合观测网 compare to the observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems in terms of frequency and variety of parameters measured?
Comparison.Answer: The 黑河流域地表过程综合观测网 employs a 10-minute observation frequency and measures a wide range of parameters including air temperature, humidity, pressure, precipitation, wind speed, soil moisture, and temperature profiles. In contrast, the observational datasets from oasis–desert systems include half-hourly turbulent flux data, energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in ensuring the quality and consistency of long-term data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems, and how are these addressed in data processing protocols?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in data quality and consistency include dealing with missing data, removing duplicates, and filtering out values that exceed physical or instrumental limits. These challenges are addressed by marking missing data with specific codes, ensuring uniform date and time formats, and conducting regular quality checks to flag questionable data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary causes of data loss or inaccuracies in meteorological observations in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In meteorological observations in arid regions, data loss or inaccuracies can be caused by missing data points which are marked by -6999, duplication of recorded times, and data that exceed physical significances or instrument ranges. Additionally, doubts about certain data are marked in red, which could indicate potential inaccuracies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: There is a need for long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems to achieve a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange. This understanding is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, supporting ecological security, and promoting sustainable socioeconomic development in these areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What challenges contribute to the environmental degradation observed in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges contributing to environmental degradation in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas include the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in regions along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of implementing long-term observational datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Implementing long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial for achieving a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which supports the ecological stability, socioeconomic development of oases, and helps in recognizing oasis–desert interactions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of integrating datasets involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from the middle and lower reaches of arid regions for understanding carbon cycles?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating datasets involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from arid regions can significantly enhance the understanding of carbon cycles by providing comprehensive data that help in assessing the role of oasis–desert areas as carbon sinks and their impact on the global carbon cycle.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems, which are crucial for achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality. This understanding supports ecological security and sustainable development in oases by recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protecting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to include detailed hydrometeorological data in datasets related to arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Including detailed hydrometeorological data is important to address the ecological challenges faced by inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas, such as ecological environment degradation, drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, and intensification of land desertification. These data help in understanding and mitigating these challenges.

Goal Orientation.Question: What motivates the integration of vegetation and soil parameters with energy and water vapor exchange data in oasis–desert studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Integrating vegetation and soil parameters with energy and water vapor exchange data is motivated by the need to provide a comprehensive understanding of the interactions within oasis–desert systems. This integration is significant for recognizing oasis–desert interactions, supporting ecological stability, and facilitating sustainable oasis development by ensuring a balanced ecological environment.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring the quality and accuracy of meteorological data collected from automated weather stations in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures include ensuring a daily collection of 144 data points at 10-minute intervals, marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that are physically implausible or exceed instrument range, and marking questionable data in red. Date and time are formatted consistently, and the data is named following a specific rule for identification.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are the soil parameters and vegetation data incorporated into the analysis of oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil parameters such as soil temperature, moisture profiles, and soil heat flux are measured using buried sensors at various depths. These parameters are supplemented along with vegetation data to provide auxiliary information for the comprehensive analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the technical steps involved in setting up an automated meteorological station in a desert environment to monitor climatic variables?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Setting up an automated meteorological station involves installing various sensors at specified heights and orientations, such as air temperature and humidity sensors at 5m and 10m facing north, wind sensors at 5m and 10m, and a rain gauge at 10m. Other sensors include four-component radiometers, infrared thermometers, and soil probes at various depths, all positioned strategically relative to the meteorological tower to capture accurate environmental data.

Enablement.Question: How do data processing and quality control procedures ensure the accuracy and reliability of collected data in harsh environments?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing and quality control procedures involve ensuring a consistent number of daily data points, removing duplicate records, deleting data outside physical or instrument limits, marking questionable data, and standardizing data formats to ensure accuracy and reliability.

Enablement.Question: What factors enable the integration of long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux observations with hydrometeorological and soil parameters?
Enablement.Answer: The integration is enabled by establishing a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations that consistently collect relevant data, including fluxes and auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters, ensuring comprehensive coverage over extended periods.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated challenges in maintaining data accuracy and consistency when collecting long-term meteorological data in arid and semiarid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges include ensuring data completeness (144 data points per day), eliminating duplicated records, removing data that exceed physical limits or instrument ranges, and dealing with ecological degradation such as land desertification and dust storms which can impact data collection.

Expectation.Question: How can researchers enhance the reliability of data collected from automatic weather stations in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Reliability can be enhanced by implementing rigorous data processing and quality control procedures, such as standardizing date-time formats, marking questionable data, and following naming conventions for datasets to facilitate data archiving and sharing.

Expectation.Question: What methods can be employed to expand datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas to better support sustainable development goals?
Expectation.Answer: Methods include establishing additional land surface flux and meteorological stations, incorporating auxiliary data on vegetation and soil parameters, and integrating data from both artificial and natural systems to provide comprehensive insights into oasis-desert interactions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period for collecting hydrometeorological data in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Automatic weather stations are effective in collecting detailed and frequent hydrometeorological data, such as radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and air parameters, which are crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in maintaining long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid regions, and how might they affect data reliability?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges include ecological degradation, such as drying rivers and lakes, and dust storms, which can disrupt data collection and affect the reliability of long-term datasets. Ensuring data quality requires robust data processing, quality control, and consistent monitoring efforts.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the key considerations for expanding datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Key considerations include integrating data from various sources, such as remote sensing and field observations, ensuring data consistency and quality control, and addressing ecological impacts on data collection. Collaborating with data centers like the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center can enhance dataset availability and comprehensiveness.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the data collection at different depths for soil temperature and moisture can be accurately maintained and processed over a long period.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection involves using soil temperature and moisture sensors buried at various depths (0cm, 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 60cm, 100cm) which are positioned strategically around the meteorological tower. Data is collected every 10 minutes, ensuring consistent monitoring. Quality control involves checking for missing data, removing duplicates, and ensuring the data falls within expected physical ranges.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the data from different sensors, such as those measuring radiation and soil heat flux, are integrated to study oasis–desert interactions.
Assertion.Answer: The integration of data from sensors measuring various parameters like air temperature, humidity, wind speed, radiation, and soil heat flux is crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. This comprehensive data collection from automatic weather stations over a long-term period allows for detailed analysis of oasis–desert interactions and supports ecological and socioeconomic assessments.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data processing and quality control techniques used in collecting comprehensive meteorological data from automatic weather stations in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data processing and quality control involved ensuring daily completeness with 144 data entries (one every 10 minutes), marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data outside of physical or instrumental limits, and marking questionable data in red. It also included standardizing the date and time format, with both included in a single column.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the methods used for integrating hydrometeorological data with soil and vegetation parameters in oasis–desert ecosystem observations.
Request/Directive.Answer: The integration involved using automatic weather stations to observe hydrometeorological data such as radiation, soil heat flux, and temperature profiles, as well as gradients of air temperature, humidity, wind speed, direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture. This was supplemented by additional vegetation and soil parameters to provide a comprehensive dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in maintaining long-term data collection networks in inland river basins of arid and semiarid regions, particularly with respect to ecological environment degradation.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include ecological environment degradation such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are especially prevalent in inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin, Aral Sea basin, and Lake Urmia basin.
